issues.text: whether the debt of the father was avyavaharika

anchor.surface_text: The first question for decision is whether the debt of the father was avyavaharika. This term has been variously translated as being that which is not lawful or what is not just or what is not admissible under the law or under normal conditions.

holdings.text: The debt was not avyavaharika as negligence by the managing director in investing bank monies is not repugnant to good morals.

anchor.surface_text: The managing director of a Bank of the position of defendant No. 1 who should have been more vigilant in investing the monies of the Bank cannot be said to have incurred the liability for a cause repugnant to good morals .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Colebrooke's translation adopted; distinguished from criminal breach of trust; modern banking context precludes immorality label; no admissible evidence of immorality.

holdings.text: Any opinion in the Deputy Registrar's order on the nature of liability is inadmissible to prove if debt was avyavaharika.

anchor.surface_text: Any opinion given in the order of the Deputy Registrar as to the nature of the liability of defendant No.1, M. B. Jakati, cannot be used as evidence in the present case to determine whether the debt was avyavaharika or otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S. 43 Indian Evidence Act limits judgments to proving existence, not truth of facts unless in rem or public interest.

holdings.text: Pious obligation of sons to pay father's non-immoral debts continues post-partition; father's alienation power ends but creditor's execution right over whole estate unaffected.

anchor.surface_text: the pious obligation of the sons to discharge the debt of the father. The pious obligation continues to exist even though the power of the father to alienate may come to an end as a result of partition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents like Panna Lal, Sidheshwar Mukherji affirm obligation independent of father's power; partition changes enjoyment mode only.

holdings.text: In execution, no need to implead sons post-partition or file new suit; father represents sons; attachment unaffected.

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises how the liability of the sons is to be enforced. Another principle of Hindu law is that in a coparcenary family the decree obtained against the father

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sons represented by father-karta; S.64 CPC analogous; pious duty persists; distinguished Ganpatrao, Kameshwaramma as fact-specific.

holdings.text: Under s.155 Bombay Land Revenue Code, 'right, title and interest of defaulter' is question of fact; here whole coparcenary bungalow sold.

anchor.surface_text: The property put up for sale was plot No. 36 -D measuring 6 acres and one guntha and its value was specified as 13,000 rupees. There was a

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents (proclamation, confirmation, certificate) show whole property valued/sold; precedents like Meenakshi Naidu determine by intent.

holdings.text: Words 'right, title and interest' in s.155 BLRC same as in CPC; sale effect identical.

anchor.surface_text: The argument based on the interpretation of the words I right, title and interest of the defaulter in s. 155 of the Bombay Land Revenue Code was that it was only the share

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical equivalence; supported by precedents; substance over technicality.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed; High Court correct that whole estate sold, binding on sons.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings to facts.
